Hello and welcome to this prerecorded event
for delivering Pearson's new AS and A level

16.text:
To help you get the most out of this session,
you may want to have the following documents

25.text:
handy as I will refer to them during the session:
A level Economics B specification

33.text:
AS Economics B sample assessment materials
A level Economics B sample assessment materials

42.text:
Getting started guide
All of these documents can be downloaded from

47.text:
the Economics B subject page on the Pearson
qualifications website.

54.text:
Let's start by reminding ourselves of the
specification structure.

62.text:
There are four themes on the A level specification.
Theme 1 looks at markets, consumers and firms,

70.text:
while theme 2 focuses on the wider economic
environment, including introducing life in

76.text:
a global economy. These themes have the same
content for both the AS and A level qualification.

84.text:
Theme 3 builds on the content in theme 2,
exploring the global economy in more depth.

91.text:
Theme 4 builds on theme 1 content, exploring
how markets work. This theme includes a look

99.text:
at risk and the financial sector.
There are two externally examined papers for

110.text:
the AS qualification; theme 1 is assessed
in paper 1 and theme 2 is assessed in paper

118.text:
2.
The content for theme 1 and theme 2 is the

122.text:
same for the AS and A level qualifications.
This means that even though the AS and A level

129.text:
qualifications are separate, you can co-teach
them more on this later.

140.text:
There are three externally examined papers
for the A level qualification; theme 1 and

146.text:
theme 4 are assessed in paper 1, theme 2 and
theme 3 are assessed in paper 2, and paper

155.text:
3 assesses content from across the entire
course, bringing all the concepts together.

160.text:
Paper 3 has a pre-released context, which
will be made available to centres in November

167.text:
(6 months before the exam) to enable you to
use this context in the classroom.

175.text:
Linear courses with all exams taken at the
end may require different teaching approaches.

185.text:
Before we look at theme 1 in detail, the next
slides introduce some things you might like

190.text:
to think about or things you might do already!
For most students, economics is a new subject

203.text:
for A level and is very different from other
subjects they've studied at GCSE.

208.text:
Linking the economic theory to real-life business
contexts, news stories and data can show students

215.text:
how 'economics works' and support them in
building confidence with the subject from

220.text:
the very beginning. Many students have told
us that they choose economics because it's

226.text:
relevant to what they see in the news so introducing
this from the outset helps to reinforce that

232.text:
the subject is all around them.
Linked to building confidence is building

242.text:
student interest in the subject.
As we've mentioned, linking the economic theory

248.text:
to real-world situations students are aware
of can help to build enthusiasm for the subject.

256.text:
The specification content has been updated
to reflect developments and current issues

261.text:
in economics. For example, the introduction
of the financial sector supports student understanding

268.text:
of recent economic events and the 2008 global
financial crisis.

276.text:
Our specification places emphasis on real
business contexts and how these relate to

281.text:
economics; for example, real business contexts
are used in all the exam papers. From the

289.text:
start of the course you can introduce businesses
that students know and are engaged by. When

295.text:
the pre-released context is made available
in November of year 13, you may wish to use

302.text:
this as a context in the classroom or use
as a basis for independent research.

307.text:
The purpose of the pre-released context is
to provide an engaging context that can be

313.text:
used meaningfully throughout the teaching
and learning, in addition to providing a familiar

319.text:
context for students in the exam. The purpose
is not to get teachers or students to complete

326.text:
huge amounts of resources so you can introduce
the context in a way that best suits your

331.text:
students.
We've included skills for university progression

341.text:
throughout the course.
As part of this, our papers have a range of

345.text:
extended writing questions (ranging from 8
to 20 marks in the A level) and there will

351.text:
be plenty of opportunities for students to
practise their extended writing. Remember

357.text:
that as A levels are now linear qualifications,
all papers are taken at the end of the course

363.text:
so students develop extended writing throughout
the course of study. Our research showed that

370.text:
universities were keen for A level students
to develop extended writing skills, demonstrating

375.text:
their ability to build and sustain economic
arguments.

385.text:
Our research with HE showed that critical
thinking is one of the key skills universities

391.text:
are looking for in economics students.
Universities want students to appreciate that

398.text:
there is not always a right answer and that
economics can be debated. By developing the

405.text:
ability to 'think like an economist', students
will have a toolkit of concepts that they

411.text:
can apply to a range of familiar and unfamiliar
contexts as they progress through A level

416.text:
and into further study. By introducing business
contexts, students will practise applying

424.text:
economic theory to real-life scenarios and
explore the limitations of theories and models.

430.text:
Throughout the course you could use a range
of questioning techniques to support students

436.text:
in developing as economic thinkers, for example:
Allowing time for thinking.

443.text:
Closed/open questions.
Asking several students without revealing

449.text:
answer (or not revealing answer at all)
Demanding a reason to explain correct response.

458.text:
Exploring why an incorrect response is wrong.
When setting written work, you could set at

464.text:
least one question that isn't straightforward
to encourage students to debate different

469.text:
viewpoints.
Students are required to develop and demonstrate

479.text:
competence in quantitative skills for economics.
It's important for these skills to be applied

486.text:
to relevant economic contexts to ensure students
develop a holistic understanding of the application

492.text:
of quantitative skills to economics this isn't
about 'doing lots of maths' in isolation but

499.text:
using appropriate quantitative skills in the
appropriate economic contexts. Students will

507.text:
already be familiar with most of the skills
through their study of GCSE maths and it is

512.text:
important to demonstrate how these mathematical
skills are relevant to the study of economics.

519.text:
In addition to the content requirements in
the specification, these skills can also be

524.text:
developed through the use of stimulus material
and case studies, providing opportunities

530.text:
for students to apply a range of quantitative
skills to analyse real economic issues. This

536.text:
stimulus material should take the form of
both qualitative and quantitative information.

548.text:
Our thematic structure enables students to
develop knowledge and understanding as they

553.text:
progress through the course.
This means that they are encouraged to reinforce

558.text:
concepts they have studied at the beginning
of the course later on. For example, students

565.text:
are introduced to economics through building
knowledge and application of concepts in theme

570.text:
1 and theme 2, with breadth and depth of knowledge
and understanding, and applications to more

576.text:
complex concepts and models developed in theme
3 and theme 4. This supports continuous progression

584.text:
throughout the whole A level course of study.
We're now going to summarise the highlights

594.text:
in theme 1.
You might want to refer to the specification

599.text:
(or have your hard copy to hand) as we go
this section. You can also refer to the getting

606.text:
started guide, which includes teaching and
learning ideas for each topic.

617.text:
Theme 1 introduces students to the economic
problem, market failure and government intervention.

625.text:
Students will explore the ways in which consumers
make choices and entrepreneurs create desirable

631.text:
products. Students will apply knowledge and
understanding of both familiar and unfamiliar

637.text:
contexts in the assessments, and demonstrate
an awareness of current economic events and

642.text:
policies. Students should have knowledge of
the UK economy in the last 10 years.

651.text:
Highlights in this theme include:
Consumer choices and enterprise in the economy

658.text:
The market economy and how market forces shape
the way in which firms meet consumer demand

665.text:
The role of banks in the economy.
This topic introduces the basic economic concepts

677.text:
and what the study of economics entails.
These are the fundamental concepts that will

684.text:
reoccur throughout all the themes, and students
will be expected to be able to use these concepts

690.text:
in both economic and business contexts. Scarcity
and choice should be taught from a theoretical

697.text:
viewpoint, but students should be able to
apply these to the choices made by individuals,

703.text:
businesses and governments on a day-to-day
basis. Examples of conflicts that arise from

709.text:
scarce resources should be developed, and
students will be expected to evaluate the

715.text:
strategies used and the impact on economic
agents such as consumers, producers and the

722.text:
government.
The objectives of firms should be considered

726.text:
for different sizes of businesses ranging
from small sole traders to large multinationals.

735.text:
Students should also develop an appreciation
that not all firms aim to maximise profit

740.text:
and that there may be ethical considerations
for social enterprises such as One Water.

748.text:
Economic agents (stakeholders) are integral
to the course and are introduced here along

754.text:
with stakeholder conflicts.
This topic considers the role and importance

765.text:
of the entrepreneur in the economy.
Entrepreneurs create firms by combining the

770.text:
factors of production: land, labour and capital.
Students will need to understand this process,

779.text:
and that the quality and amount of these resources
can determine the success of an economy. The

787.text:
impact of the division of labour and of specialisation
on businesses and individuals is considered,

794.text:
before a first look at the wider economy.
This section is an introduction to what these

800.text:
terms mean and a consideration of their impact
on businesses. Deeper understanding of their

806.text:
causes and policy solutions is explored in
theme 4.

816.text:
This topic covers all aspects of the market,
from basic definitions, through the forces

822.text:
that allocate resources, to an understanding
of how to use market information to improve

827.text:
the prospects of the firm.
This is an important section as much of what

833.text:
follows in this theme and themes 2, 3 and
4 rely on a sound understanding of the workings

840.text:
of the market. Students need not just understand
the theoretical background of the market but

847.text:
must also be able to apply it to real-life
situations. They may be required to use suitably

854.text:
labelled demand and supply diagrams to show
the impact of changing market conditions.

866.text:
Firms need finance for a number of different
reasons: to cover start-up costs, to ensure

872.text:
adequate cash to operate or for day-to-day
costs, and to invest in expanding the business.

880.text:
This topic considers the role of credit in
the economy. Although firms need to borrow

885.text:
for capital investment and working capital,
borrowing can be both costly and risky. Students

893.text:
will develop an understanding of the role
of banks in the economy and the importance

897.text:
of liability. Starting a new firm involves
numerous costs. Some of these will be large

905.text:
one-off payments for things like premises
and equipment and can be considerable. The

910.text:
firm may also need finance to keep paying
costs such as wages and raw materials until

917.text:
enough income comes in from its sales. If
all goes well, the firm will be successful

924.text:
and make a profit. However, this does not
mean that the firm will have enough cash on

930.text:
a day-to-day basis to pay its bills. It may
well need additional finance to provide sufficient

937.text:
working capital to cope with any cash-flow
problems. There may come a time when the firm

944.text:
will want to expand. This may involve extra
finance to pay for it. Firms must decide between

952.text:
different types of credit and finance, and
be aware of the challenge of obtaining credit.

964.text:
Theme 1 has already explored the workings
of the market in a mostly theoretical manner;

970.text:
for example, that the free market allocates
resources in response to consumer demand and

976.text:
that free markets work efficiently. These
topics introduce the idea that markets often

981.text:
do not produce the required results and actually
create problems that need to be addressed.

988.text:
The topic begins with what these problems
are and how markets fail. In order to correct

996.text:
these market failures, some form of government
intervention is needed. The topic then considers

1003.text:
how governments can and do intervene. Government
intervention does not always solve the problems

1010.text:
and can make them worse or create problems
elsewhere. This is the concept of market failure.

1017.text:
This section should refer to real-life examples
whenever possible.

1025.text:
This topic introduces students to financial
techniques for measuring the way a business

1033.text:
is performing.
Firms need to be able to measure their performance

1038.text:
and know when to take remedial action. Students
will be expected to know how to make a range

1044.text:
of calculations, apply them and interpret
them. They will need to know what the results

1051.text:
show and be able to make comparisons and draw
conclusions.

This slide provides an overview of one way
you might approach planning for these new

1066.text:
topics.
Have a look at the planning activity documents

1071.text:
for theme 1. The purpose of these resources
is to demonstrate an approach to building

1076.text:
a bank of knowledge/background information

1081.text:
of the specification coverage. The approach
taken in this resource is to identify:

1088.text:
What do students need to know? (You can use

1093.text:

What examples can you use to illustrate this

1099.text:
(to support students with application). (You
can refer to resources such as our scheme

1104.text:
of work to help.)
What causes and consequences/linkages can

1110.text:
you think of?
What evaluative points can be made?

1115.text:
How can this content be revisited later in
the specification where are the links?

1122.text:
How will you revise this when teaching themes
3 and 4?

1127.text:
If you think this approach will work for you
and your department, why not adapt them for

1134.text:
each topic so you can build a bank of resources.

Exemplar student work and examiner commentaries

Our national training programme of events

specification in 2015. Look out for support

mocks marking in 2016.
